There are a bunch of theories about how early religion formed. Of course - as Jo says, that God caused it is one of them; and one that you haven't really given a good reason for discarding, Accipter (agnosticism FTW :p). 
 
 Terry Pratchett's done a bunch of different stories about the origins of religion. Small Gods is the more fictional, where the strength of a god depends on the number of their followers. The Science of Discworld series, however, gives more plausible stories. It describes early religion as mans attempt to describe an inexplicably chaotic world. Early man would have seen that some things, he could control (which rock to bang on which head, for example) but that some things, he could not (being eaten by lions). "Presumably," runs the trail of his thought, "if I can control the rocks, then who else is controlling the lions, the thunder and the rain?" It's not too big a step from there to the thought "so how can I persuade the lion-controllers to be nice to me?" All you need then is for an enterprising individual to claim that following his commands, along with a non-measurable requirement like 'having faith', is enough to stop the lions eating you. The non-measurable command is essential; then you can say "Oh, Henry got eaten by the lions? Well, he can't have had enough faith!". 
 If you do that for long enough - ensuring that the 'follow my orders' bit becomes a self-fulfilling prophecy, where not following orders results in you being thrown to the lions - then you can see why the Cult of the Lion would suddenly expand.
 
 The series had a more complicated version for the Abrahamic religions, but I don't remember the details well enough to replicate them here, and my copies of the books are about 60 miles away... all three of the books are well worth a read though.

 Man has always tried to explain what he does not understand, generally by telling himself stories - be it about 'Zeus throwing spears' or about 'electrons getting excited'. In both cases, personification has a tendency to creep in, because a successful story is one which is believable; and people like to relate to things.
